scoring_rules.content: Bronze Level Baseline: Award 50 points if the packaging strictly complies with French Law AGEC and REACH regulations, ensuring no prohibited substances are used.
Essential Functionality: Deduct 20 points if any packaging component does not serve a critical function (protection, transport, information) and is purely decorative[cite: 106].
Recycling Stream Existence: Deduct 30 points if the primary material does not have an operational recycling stream in France (e.g., PLA, PVC, PSE)[cite: 383].
Mono-Material Bonus: Add 15 points if the entire packaging unit is made of a single material (e.g., 100% paperboard or 100% PE), facilitating easy recycling[cite: 354].
Separability Score: If multi-material is necessary (e.g., barrier film on tray), add 10 points only if components are easily separable by the consumer (e.g., peelable film)[cite: 665].
Weight Reduction: Add 5 points for every 10% reduction in packaging weight compared to the previous version or market average[cite: 343].
Volume Optimization: Deduct 15 points if the 'void rate' (empty space inside the packaging) exceeds 20%, unless necessary for product protection[cite: 346].
Recycled Content (Silver Level): Add 10 points if the packaging contains at least 30% Post-Consumer Recycled (PCR) material[cite: 627].
High Recycled Content: Add 20 points if the packaging contains over 50% recycled content (e.g., rPET bottles for plant milks)[cite: 627].
FSC/PEFC Certification: Mandatory for wood/paper. [cite_start]Deduct 50 points (disqualification from Silver/Gold) if fiber-based materials are not certified sustainable[cite: 474].
Bio-sourced Material (Silver Level): Add 10 points for bio-sourced materials (e.g., bio-PE) only if they are chemically identical to their fossil counterparts and fully recyclable[cite: 485].
Gold Level Innovation: Award 100 points for a completely package-free solution (bulk) or a validated reuse/deposit scheme[cite: 607].
Reuse Design: Add 20 points if the packaging is designed to be washable and refillable for at least 10 cycles[cite: 372].

Plastic Substitution: Add 15 points for successfully replacing a plastic component with a fiber-based alternative (e.g., cardboard tray instead of plastic tray) without compromising shelf life[cite: 471].
Dark Plastics Penalty: Deduct 25 points for using Carbon Black (dark plastics) as they are undetectable by optical sorters in recycling centers.
Inks & Glues: Deduct 10 points if inks or glues exceed 5% of total weight or use heavy metals that contaminate the recycling batch[cite: 394].

Intrinsic Quality - Preservation Barrier: Allocate up to 30% of the total score for properties that prevent food waste (key for plant-based sensitivity), specifically anti-oxidation and moisture barriers[cite: 101, 113].
Intrinsic Quality - Mechanical Robustness: Ensure high shock resistance to protect fragile plant-based textures during logistics, avoiding product loss (solidité)[cite: 113].
Intrinsic Quality - Ergonomics & Portioning: Award points for tool-free opening systems and portionable formats that allow consumers to use only what they need, minimizing waste[cite: 113].

Consumer Attractiveness - Aesthetic Weighting: Allocate 25% of the score to aesthetics, prioritizing natural colors and modern minimalist designs that visually cue 'plant-based' without clutter[cite: 113].
Consumer Attractiveness - Marketing Integrity: Award points for appetizing visuals that avoid 'greenwashing' and ensure prominent, legible 'plant-based' and nutritional labeling[cite: 113].
Consumer Attractiveness - Intent to Purchase: Validate the design with a Gold Level requirement of >80% approval in consumer intent-to-purchase surveys.
Practical Utility - Portability & Reusability: Allocate 20% of the score for features that enhance portability (lightweight, stackable) and enable reuse (rechargeable containers)[cite: 371].

Practical Utility - User Experience (UX): Prioritize intuitive handling and compatibility with modern habits (e.g., microwave/fridge safe) for the convenience-seeking plant-based demographic[cite: 113].

material_heuristics.content: Prioritize Paper/Cardboard: For plant-based dry goods or frozen items, cardboard is the preferred material due to its high recycling rate and renewable origin.
Clear PET for Liquids: For plant-based milks and oils, use transparent PET (not opaque or colored) to ensure detection by optical sorters.
Avoid Multi-Layer Cartons if Possible: While common for plant milks, Tetra-style cartons are harder to recycle than mono-PE or mono-PET. Only use if shelf-life requires it.
PEHD for Rigids: For tubs (yogurt alternatives, spreads), rigid PEHD is preferred over PP in some regions, but both are generally acceptable if mono-material.
Molded Pulp Trays: Replace plastic trays for fresh produce or sturdy plant-based meats with molded pulp, ensuring any liners are peelable.
No PVC Cling Film: PVC is a major contaminant. Use PE-based cling films for wrapping fresh plant-based cuts.
Avoid Polystyrene (PSE/PS): Eliminate PS for yogurt pots or trays; it has no long-term recycling viability in France. Switch to PET or cardboard.
Bio-PE vs. PLA: Prefer Bio-PE (from sugarcane) over PLA. Bio-PE recycles with standard PE; PLA often ends up in incineration if not industrially composted.
Aluminium Utility: Aluminum is excellent for high-barrier needs (long shelf life plant pâtés) and is infinitely recyclable.
Wood for Logistics: Wood (pallets, crates) is excellent but must be treated/clean and ideally reused, not just recycled.
Complex Laminates Warning: Avoid paper/plastic laminates where the plastic content is >50% but it looks like paper. This is greenwashing and hard to recycle.
Barrier Coatings: If using paper for moist plant-based meats, use water-based dispersion coatings rather than PE-lamination to facilitate repulping.
Carbon Black Free: If black packaging is required for premium plant-based branding, use carbon-black-free dyes that are NIR-detectable.
Glass for Reuse Only: Glass has a high carbon footprint for single use. Use it only if a deposit/return scheme is in place.
Vegetable Inks: Specify vegetable-based inks for all printing to reduce chemical toxicity in the recycling sludge.
Adhesive Compatibility: Use water-soluble adhesives (hot-melt) that wash off at <60°C during the recycling wash process.
Direct Print on PET: Avoid large shrink sleeves on PET bottles. Direct printing or small paper labels are preferred.
Cork/Wood Stoppers: Avoid combining natural stoppers (cork/wood) with plastic bottles; they are contaminants.
Ceramic/Stoneware: Avoid for single-use. They are generally not recyclable in household streams.
Flexible Pouches: Mono-PE pouches are emerging as recyclable, but ensure they are not multi-layer PE/PET laminates.

packaging_patterns.content: The 'Burger Sleeve' Strategy: Replace full cardboard boxes for frozen patties with a simple paper band or thinner cardboard sleeve to reduce material by 40%.
Skin-Pack for Fresh: Use skin-pack technology (thin film vacuum sealed to card) for fresh plant meat. It extends shelf life (reducing food waste) and uses 70% less plastic than MAP trays.
Window Removal: Remove plastic viewing windows from nugget/finger food boxes. Use high-quality photography to depict the product instead.
Bulk Bins: For dry plant proteins (TVP, lentils), design packaging for bulk gravity bins rather than individual 500g bags.
Concentrates: Sell plant milks as concentrates or powders to reduce water transport and packaging volume by 90%.
Paper-Based Multipacks: Replace plastic shrink wrap on plant milk multipacks with cardboard clips or paper adhesives.
Reusable E-commerce: For D2C plant-based frozen shipments, use reusable insulated totes (like wool-cool or reusable plastic) instead of Styrofoam.
Stackability: Redesign rigid containers to be rectangular rather than round to optimize pallet density and reduce transport emissions.
Right-Sizing: Use 'box-on-demand' technology in fulfillment centers to ensure the shipping box exactly fits the product, eliminating void fill.
Tethered Caps: Ensure all beverage caps (plant milks) are tethered to the bottle/carton to prevent littering (EU mandatory).
Flexible Refills: Sell the main product in a durable glass/steel jar, and refills in lightweight mono-material pouches.
Edible Coatings: Explore edible, plant-based coatings (e.g., Apeel) for fresh produce to eliminate wrapping entirely.
Paper-Based Tape: Replace plastic packing tape with water-activated paper tape for logistics boxes.
Mono-Material Lidding: For dips/spreads, use a PET lid on a PET tub, rather than an aluminum foil seal, to keep it 100% mono-material.
Reusable Pallet Wraps: Switch from single-use stretch film to reusable pallet wraps/nets for internal logistics.
Padless Meat Trays: Design trays with honeycomb structures to absorb juices naturally, eliminating the need for a separate non-recyclable absorbent pad.
Label-Free: Use laser engraving for Best Before dates and batch codes directly on the packaging surface.
Flat-Pack Design: Design primary packaging to fold flat when empty, encouraging consumers to recycle and saving waste bin space.
Sample Sizes in Paper: Distribute marketing samples in paper sachets rather than mini plastic flow-wraps.
The 'Naked' Product: For robust vegetables or fruits, sell loose with only a sticker, completely removing the bag.

go_to_market_rules.content: Triman Logo Mandatory: You must display the Triman logo + sorting instructions on all recyclable packaging sold in France (Law AGEC).
Ban on 'Biodegradable': Do not use the word 'Biodegradable' on packaging. It is vague and prohibited in France for being misleading. Use 'Compostable' only if certified.
Compostable Claims: You cannot claim 'Compostable' if it is only industrially compostable and no collection stream exists for consumers.
Penalty Avoidance: Ensure your plastic has a recycling stream to avoid the 2022 malus/penalty imposed by the state on non-recyclable plastics.
Recycled Content Claim: You can claim 'Made from X% recycled material' but must be able to prove traceability.
Single-Use Plastic Reduction: Explicitly state efforts to reduce single-use plastic, as this aligns with the 2025/2030 reduction goals of the Law AGEC.
QR Code Education: Use a QR code to link to a 'Sustainability Journey' page, explaining how to reuse or recycle the pack, as space on-pack is limited.
Transparency on Origin: Clearly state where the packaging is made. 'Made in France' packaging appeals to local sustainability values.
Bio-sourced Clarity: If using bio-sourced plastic, clarify it is 'Plant-based PE' and '100% Recyclable' to avoid confusion with biodegradable plastics.
Avoid Greenwashing: Do not use vague terms like 'Eco-friendly' or 'Green' without specific, substantiated qualifiers.
Consumer Sorting Nudges: Use color-coding on packs (e.g., Yellow for plastic/metal bins) to help consumers sort correctly.
Separation Instructions: If components must be separated (e.g., pot and cardboard sleeve), explicitly instruct the consumer: 'Remove sleeve to recycle'.
Date Marking Visibility: Ensure Use-By dates are legible to prevent food waste, which has a higher impact than packaging waste.
Eco-Modulation: Design packaging to qualify for CITEO eco-modulation bonuses (e.g., off-white PET, rigid PE) to reduce producer fees.
Reuse Labeling: If the packaging is reusable, it must be labeled as such with clear instructions on how to return or refill it.
Plastic-Free Logo: Use a 'Plastic Free' certification mark (like A Plastic Planet) if the product is genuinely 100% plastic-free.
B2B Communication: For foodservice (catering), clearly label bulk packaging for proper back-of-house sorting.
No Littering: Include the 'Do not litter' (Tidy Man) symbol, especially for snacking products.
Local Recycling Rules: Include a disclaimer 'Check local recycling rules' if exporting to regions with different systems than France.
Marketing Consistency: Ensure the packaging material aligns with the brand ethos. A vegan/plant-based product in heavy, non-recyclable plastic creates cognitive dissonance for consumers.
